post_text: Thank you Austin Avanza for recognizing Stacy K Danielson Middle School Dual Language teacher Adrian Velasquez in your Spotlight Series for Hispanic/Latinx Heritage Month. We are so proud of Señor Valasquez & his many accomplishments at #1LISD. May your success endeavors continue to pour into our students!
shared_text:
Austin Avanza
22 hrs ·

We're kicking off our Austin Avanza Hispanic/Latinx Heritage Month Educator Spotlight Series! Our first spotlight goes to Adrian Velásquez, an incredible Dual Language Educator in the Austin Metro Area! He's helping build a middle school dual language program is also completing his Principal certification program this year. Our students are lucky to have such an incredible leader as their educator!

Know another amazing Hispanic/Latinx educator in the region, let us know, we plan tto spotlight a different educator everyday during Hispanic/Latinx Heritage Month.

Knowles ES: We are excited to announce that our new neighbors @Burlington and @adoptaclassroom have generously donated $5,000 in school supplies for our classrooms! post_text:
For her remarkable effort and passion for new discoveries, we’re celebrating LISD Super Kid Delaney Hoffman!

The ParksideElementary fourth-grader embodies the 12 Parkside Scholar Traits both in and outside of the classroom. Among them include continually improving, making connections and demonstrating perseverance. These characteristics have played a big part of Delaney’s success.

“Laney always strives to do her best work!” her teacher Casey Koester said. “She takes the initiative to hop back onto Zoom during her asynchronous time if she has any questions. She is constantly thinking and asking great questions.”

Beyond her own academic success, Laney shines with kindness, always encouraging her classmates.

A can-do attitude + a compassionate heart for others = Delaney Hoffman–LISD Super Kid! Congratulations!

Let's stay strong, together, and focused on keeping healthy.

We will welcome three new grade levels, students receiving dyslexia services, and the children of substitute teachers back for in-person learning Sept. 21 for Phase 2 of our Launch to Learning. Thank you to our families, teachers, and staff for your continued partnership.

Here's a message from Superintendent Bruce Gearing, Ed.D. about our reopening plans.

post_text:
A dual threat on the field and in the classroom, Vista Ridge High School senior Kyle Brown is showing he has what it takes as Leander ISD Student-Athlete of the Week!

Captain of the Ranger varsity football team, Kyle serves on the team’s Leadership Council. During the spring, Kyle plays baseball for the Rangers. As an A/B honor roll student, he has been Academic All-District for two years in both football and baseball.

“Kyle is a tremendous competitor in football and baseball,” VRHS head football coach Rodney Vincent said. “In addition to being a multi-sport athlete, he has represented our program so well in the classroom. I am just as proud of the way he has developed and worked at being a leader on the field as he has off the field.”

bit.ly/SAotw0914

post_text: 19 years later. We remember the 2,977 people who died in New York City, Washington, DC and outside Shanksville, PA. We honor the men and women who heroically saved lives and defended our freedom. We embrace teaching more than just a history lesson, but how the events of 9/11/01 continue to reverberate through our lives.

That's why we want to share with you what kinds of things your secondary students will experience when they return. A huge thank you to our staff & families who have offered valuable input to help create healthy & safe #1LISD schools.

More detailed information can be found in our Launch to Learning Handbook: bit.ly/L2LHandbook

post_text:
We know technical issues regarding connectivity and access to live, face-to-face virtual learning has caused stress to our students and teachers. Our tech team achieved a significant breakthrough today, doubling our bandwidth.

As of Tuesday afternoon, our tech team has completed the following steps to improve connectivity:

- installed five additional servers (totaling 17) for content filtering in our data center,
- added 10 cloud servers to increase capacity through our content filtering system, and
- doubled our bandwidth from 10 GB to 20 GB.

We are still asking students to complete these instructions on all district-issued, mLISD Lenovo laptops with the 7.31 version of its student VPN software.

Families, students, and staff can continue to submit individual support issues through our Help Desk or Let’s Talk. We are experiencing a high volume of concerns. Please be patient as we respond as quickly as possible. bit.ly/techupd0818

post_text:
It was a wild day at Winkley for the first day of school. Kids learned and laughed like a normal return to school. But it was wild to not see them in person. We want kids in our classrooms, when it’s safe to do so.

This third grade team - including the pictured Carmen Steplight, Nancy Reed, and Julia Whiteis - came together to collaborate, plan, and launch learning during extraordinary circumstances. Kuddos to all the teacher and school teams who worked tirelessly to think, build, and create a wonderful day 1 of 2020-21.

The Austin American Statesman visited with three these tremendous teachers to recap the start to 2020-21. Check out the story: https://www.statesman.com/news/20200813/back-to-school-central-texas-campuses-open-virtually-in-person

post_text:
Good morning for day 2 Leander ISD!!

Don’t fret if you get off to a slow start because you may just need a restart (or 2). Our tech team is working tirelessly to improve connectivity for our mLISD laptops (the Lenovos used by middle and high school students). They have remotely sent an update to the laptops overnight. You will need to:

1.) make sure the laptop is connected to the internet AND

2.) let it restart (automatically) once or twice to finalize the update.

Once enough computers load the update, connectivity should improve. We have new servers to install over the weekend so we can keep getting better and better every day (and send those high school students back to school on Monday).

Details: https://www.smore.com/0y13e-leander-isd-update

post_text:
Technology issue causes LISD to cancel the first two virtual learning days for all high school students

We are canceling school for all high school students on Thursday, Aug. 13, and Friday, Aug. 14, due to an issue with the web content filtering tool that allows students to connect to the internet on their district-provided laptop.

Elementary and middle school students will start on-time tomorrow, as scheduled. The issue does not impact Chromebooks or personal devices, which our elementary school students will be using. The web content filtering tool has the capacity for all middle school students to be logged in for our first days of the school year.

Details: https://www.smore.com/kbn7m
En Español: https://www.smore.com/2xrgm

post_text:
He loves all creatures great and small! Here’s to Leander ISD Summer Reader of the Week Tristan Pratorius-Thurman for turning his love of reading into more than just a pet project.

Tristan is heading into second grade at Camacho Elementary. Tristan’s favorite book right now is It Will Be Okay by Lysa TerKeurst. HIs favorite books make him laugh and have good pictures. He’s got plenty of company to entertain with a good book. His two dogs Lola and Little Bit, his cat named Fern, and Jumby the hamster make a great audience!

When it comes to reading, he keeps his teacher’s best advice in mind: “Don’t give up and keep trying your best.”

Congratulations LISD Summer Reader of the Week Tristan Pratorius-Thurman for pet-rifying us with his passion for books!

post_text:
A recent news story on KVUE regarding the Leander ISD dress code did not fully capture the district's approach and contained several inaccuracies. Unfortunately, the media story highlighted articles in the previous year's dress code and caused confusion in our community. LISD will present the updated dress code for the 2020-21 school year to the Board of Trustees at the Aug. 20 meeting.

We want our families to know that much grace will be given as we start the school year, and we hope that is returned. The most important thing is that our students are engaged and looking forward to learning. We strive to always provide our students with clear guidance in dressing for school in a way that is appropriate, comfortable, and allows them to learn.

post_text:
Reading for the record books! Ahmed Muein has some #biggoals. That’s what makes him Leander ISD Summer Reader of the Week!

The second-grader at Christine Camacho Elementary is currently reading The Diary of the Ice Princess. Along with reading, Ahmed likes to play Beyblades and the card game UNO. He has filled his summer stack with books about superheroes and the Fly Guy series.

“My teacher said you can make a record in reading!” Ahmed said.

While Guinness World Records doesn’t keep a record of the most books a second-grader can read, we can see Ahmed is a top contender! Besides, he’s already claiming the most important title – LISD Summer Reader of the Week! Congratulations Ahmed for using books to make it into the record books!

We know the planning for the 2020-21 school year is in everyone’s heart and on your minds. We will have our Launch to Learning 2020-21 Update 5 on Tuesday, including more details and answers for our Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ).

Good morning!

Due to the high demand for our webinars today and tomorrow, we will be streaming live on YouTube as well as on Zoom. Our Zoom account limits the webinar to 500 attendees; however, anyone can watch via YouTube.

If you cannot get into the Zoom, please visit this webpage to access the videos, which will be embedded as soon as possible.

https://news.leanderisd.org/launch-to-learning-webinars-to-air-on-youtube-available-on-demand/

The video will also be available after the webinar and we will be continuing to publish Frequently Asked Question (FAQ) responses via our webpage starting Thursday, July 9, 2020.

post_text:
Leander ISD launched a survey for all families to select preferences for opening the 2020-21 school year. The survey, which is accessible via the email for Guardian #1 (identified by the family when registering their student), will be sent from research.programevaluation@leanderisd.org.

If you are a parent or guardian to more than one student, you will get one email and links to complete the survey for each student.

The district offices are closed until July 6. When our offices re-open, we will work to create a call-in option for parents without access to technology to complete the survey over the phone. We have also offered the survey in both English and Spanish.

post_text:
GRADUATION WILL LIMIT ATTENDEES, CELEBRATE GRADUATES WITH HOUSEHOLDS TO WALK THE STAGE AT GUPTON

With graduation dates coming soon, we would like to provide our graduates and families an update regarding our ceremonies. We wish we could be together, celebrating as normally as possible. Health and safety continue to be our top priorities.

Due to the recent guidance by Texas Governor Greg Abbott, we will need to limit attendance to our ceremonies to 100 people or less. As a result, we will be hosting a ceremony where graduates will:

- celebrate graduates with their families,
- receive a diploma, and
- walk the stage at Gupton Stadium.

Unfortunately, we will not be able to celebrate with the entire class of 2020 together.

New update: https://news.leanderisd.org/graduation-will-limit-attendees-celebrate-graduates-with-households-to-walk-the-stage-at-gupton/

Graduation details: https://news.leanderisd.org/graduation-will-limit-attendees-celebrate-graduates-with-households-to-walk-the-stage-at-gupton/

post_text:
A hero among us! We’re painting the town red for LISD Super Kid Viviana Sanchez!

On the heels of wrapping up her fifth-grade year at Knowles Elementary, Viviana can look back and see how much she has helped, supported and encouraged her fellow classmates. She demonstrates honesty and respect by consistently trying to do the right thing. What stands out about Viviana is her self-awareness, working hard on the things that challenge her.

“During this remote learning phase, Viviana has shown how to be a courageous student, trying to follow all her classroom assignments and responding to all the class meetings and challenges I assign,” said Knowles Elementary Dual Language Language Arts teacher, Claudia Riccelli said. “She is an example of not allowing anyone to interfere with what you can do.”

Congratulations to our LISD Super Kid Viviana Sanchez for showing strength in courage in the face of adversity!

post_text:
Leander ISD Fine Arts Student of the Week Steven Smith is a little fish taking a big bite out of music!

In his first year in Leander High School’s choir, Steven has managed to make connections with rookie and veteran choir members alike. At the very start, his strength in leadership stood out, voted tenor section leader and serving in that role with ease. Steven also auditioned and was chosen for a vocal solo during the Winter Concert.

“Steven works very hard in class and succeeds in trying out for every opportunity in choir that comes his way! That’s amazing for a first-year choir member, if you ask me.” Leander High School assistant choir director Rob Saldaña said.

Sing your heart out, Steven Smith — Leander ISD Fine Arts Student of the Week!

post_text:
Congratulations to the students and directors of the bands from Stiles Middle School, Leander High School, and Vandegrift High School for their selections to perform at the 2020 The Midwest Clinic in Chicago!

An invitation to participate at the Midwest Clinic is considered one of the highest honors that a public school band can achieve. We believe this is the first time that three bands from a single school district have been selected to perform the same year in the 73-year history of the Clinic.

“The Midwest Clinic is the premiere performance opportunity for bands and instrumental ensembles in the world,” Leander ISD Fine Arts Director Peter Warshaw said. “The unique mix of educators and composers attending the clinic make the convention a one-of-a-kind experience for the participating students and their directors.”

The 4-day band and orchestra conference takes place in December, featuring concerts and clinics for aspiring young musicians.

Bravo to these outstanding students and to their directors!

post_text:
Recognizing Leander ISD Volunteer of the Week Gabrielle Riddell helps us show appreciation for someone who helps make teachers feel appreciated!

Gabrielle supports Cox Elementary as its volunteer coordinator. Remote learning has kept her busy, working twice as hard to ensure the school acknowledged every teacher during Teacher Appreciation Week. She coordinated and contacted all homeroom parents, establishing a plan to celebrate every teacher. Despite being busy with her own children, Gabrielle went above and beyond!

“This truly means a lot!” Cox Elementary principal Charlie Rodriguez said. “Gabrielle is always smiling, willing to support us and makes sure that we are taken care of. I am really amazed at how she coordinated Teacher Appreciation Week remotely to assure our teachers know how important they are to us. Thank you, Mrs. Riddell for all that you do!”

Three cheers for LISD Volunteer of the Week Gabrielle Riddell who goes out of her way to make sure every teacher has a brighter day!

post_text:
A Vista Ridge High School junior, armed with her newly-learned skills and her sewing machine, is helping fight the spread of COVID-19. Leander ISD Career & Technical Education (CTE) Student of the Week Gisele Nelson exemplifies what it means to not just learn, but create!

As an Intro to Fashion Design student, Gisele didn’t just settle on learning the basics of the fashion industry and construction. She completed all of her assignments and then some, launching her skills far beyond a beginner level.

Since developing that expertise, Gisele, along with her mother, chose to put those smarts to work. They’re gearing up essential workers by making masks, helping protect them amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

“Gisele is a wonderful example and mentor to her classmates as well,” Vista Ridge High School Family Consumer Science teacher Amy Kranz said.

For her weapons of “mask” construction, we’re so proud of our LISD CTE Student of the Week Gisele Nelson! Congratulations!

Leander ISD will take action steps for improving consistency, trust, and communication for students receiving special education services after a district-wide, parent-led effort to review practices and procedures.

“Continous improvement is a cornerstone of our Leander ISD culture,” Superintendent of Schools Bruce Gearing, Ed.D. said. “We are grateful to our parents and families who worked with Copia to provide insight into our practices and recommendations for our special education services.”

Click the link to review the summary and report. https://news.leanderisd.org/copia-report-released/
https://support.leanderisd.org/support/copia-report/

post_text:
Let it be known the genius behind a ‘secret’ program Carla George is Leander ISD’s Volunteer of the Week!

Carla gives her time and talent to Vandegrift High School’s Parent, Teacher, Student Association (PTSA). Over the last several years, Carla has helped establish VHS’ teacher appreciation program called “Secret Pals.” The program matches anonymous parents with a teacher to provide personalized recognition and treats throughout the entire year. This excellent staff morale booster has become a prized tradition on campus!

“Carla gives selflessly of her time and resources to support Vandegrift staff and students in a variety of ways,” Vandegrift High School principal Charles Little said. “From the ‘Secret Pal’ program, to mobilizing other parent volunteers during times of need, like the scheduling issues that happened this fall, she uses her social network to tap in to whatever it takes to support the school and our staff.”

Congratulations to LISD’s Volunteer of the Week Carla George for her heart to serve tirelessly!

Congratulations to LISD’s Volunteer of the Week Carla George for her heart to serve tirelessly!

post_text:
Our hearts go out to the class of 2020 and their families, who have watched cherished traditions altered or canceled due to the coronavirus pandemic. Our students’ safety and health is our top priority. After consultation with students and families at all six high schools and guidance from our public health partners, we are moving 2020 graduation ceremonies to July 9–11 at the HEB Center.

Superintendent Bruce Gearing, Ed.D. spoke with Cedar Park High School Senior and Wolfcast anchor Evan Vines about the plans for graduation and advice for the class of 2020.

Read the graduation plan here: https://bit.ly/3bXQhnD
text:

Our students’ safety and health is our top priority. After consultation with students and families at all six high schools and guidance from our public health partners, we are moving 2020 graduation ceremonies to July 9–11 at the HEB Center.

Superintendent Bruce Gearing, Ed.D. spoke with Cedar Park High School Senior and Wolfcast anchor Evan Vines about the plans for graduation and advice for the class of 2020.

Read the graduation plan here: https://bit.ly/3bXQhnD

LISD Super Kid John Kundukulangara-Ajith is out of this world!

The @Cox Elementary School kindergartner consistently pursues excellence. From the very beginning of the school year, John has displayed a yearning to push himself beyond his academic level. Remote learning has not slowed him down! He continues to stretch his understanding in all assignments.

“John is always going above and beyond the required assignment instructions to challenge his thinking and increase his understanding.” Cox Elementary kindergarten teacher Julie Engebretson said.

Beyond his love of learning, John lets his imagination run wild in art class and drawing. He’s also involved in Math Pentathlon.

An astronomical round of applause for LISD Super Kid John Kundukulangara-Ajith for showing Cox Comets how to reach for the stars!

post_text:
The smallest gestures are making the biggest difference thanks to Leander ISD Volunteer of the Week Zandra “Sandy” Castaneda.

Sandy serves as Reed Elementary PTA hospitality chair. She coordinates monthly surprises for teachers and staff, like treat carts and “Taco Tuesday”. For every staff member’s birthday, she celebrates each individual with a card and a soda. She’s there to help. Whether it’s helping at all of our evening events, setting up our school store, and even participating in all the parent leadership meetings.

“Sandy is a dedicated volunteer,” Reed Elementary principal Paige Collier said. “She not only supports her son Zak’s second-grade classroom, but every classroom in the school.”

For her whole heart, energy and smile, we appreciate you, LISD Volunteer of the Week Sandy Castaneda! Congratulations!

post_text:
Every morning Parkside Elementary 4th grade teacher Carolyn Bryant walks into class with a "board talk" for the day. The board talks help student start off with a positive mindset. Readjusting for a remote learning environment, Carolyn decided she wanted to continue to incorporate them into her teaching in her Zoom meetings.

Last Friday her students had a board talk called "Finish the Thought Friday". Students had to come up with a positive word to describe what they have been seeing while we shelter in place. Students wrote their words down and then everyone shared. Carolyn had the students send pictures of them holding their words. She created a video that helps celebrate what young minds are observing and learning through this health crisis. Enjoy!

post_text:
We’re shining the spotlight on Leander ISD’s Fine Arts Student of the Week Jake Jecker!

Jake is an amazing actor! The eighth grader’s performance in Henry Middle School’s UIL play Antigone was so strong that he helped the entire cast up their game. Before school closures, Jake was directing the drama club play. His passion also fueled his fire to teach theatre games every week during enrichment.

“We would not have a thriving drama club without Jake Jecker’s leadership and tireless commitment,” Henry Middle School Theatre Arts teacher Melissa Wotkyns said.

Jake’s devotion to performance doesn’t end when the curtain closes. He also helps backstage and was planning to run lights for Henry’s spring play. He even volunteered to help with an elementary school show in March.

A standing ovation for Jake Jecker–Leander ISD’s Fine Arts Student of the Week who exemplifies how being backstage is just as rewarding as being on it.

post_text:
Harry and Joyce Kilman spell out “school spirit” as our Leander ISD Volunteers of the Week!

Before the school closures, Mr. & Mrs. Kilman would come every Friday morning at 10 o’clock to change Glenn High School’s marquee. They showed up on time faithfully every single week, no matter the weather. If the marquee needs changing during a holiday or for a special occasion, they’ll get it all ready and take the letters home to change it over the weekend. Such a simple gesture helps keep messages to students current and shows just how much the Kilmans care.

“They’ve done this for us for 2 years, and they’re tougher than the postman!” said Glenn High School principal Arturo Lomeli. “The Kilmans are wonderful volunteers and great supporters of GHS at school and in the community.”

For showing us it’s great to have grandparents involved in our schools, thank you and congratulations to our LISD Volunteers of the Week Harry & Joyce Kilman!

post_text:
All school classrooms will remain closed for students through the end of the 2019–20 school year, Gov. Greg Abbott announced earlier today.

In his press conference on the state’s response to the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) global pandemic, the Governor directed school districts to Texas Education Agency (TEA) Commissioner Mike Morath for guidance on graduation and other operational decisions tied to the extended closure.

While we wish we could be in our classrooms, leading learning and celebrating the end of our year in person with our school families, we understand our community’s health and safety take precedence. We will continue to support students and families as we move forward in responding to the COVID-19 health crisis.

We will meet with our Board of Trustees next week and provide another update to families and staff on Friday, April 24.

👀 Read our entire update here: https://bit.ly/3biKzfR

Teaching and learning isn’t the only thing in LISD that’s gone virtual; evaluating and hiring job candidates has, too!

If you’re interested in applying and learning more about LISD as a destination district, check out the LISD 2020 Virtual Job Fair bit.ly/3bJmhve through April 22.

See you next Wednesday when we'll take more of your questions and find out what's happening across the best school district in the nation!
text:
Thank you to folks who tune in LIVE right here on Facebook for our show. Our full episode of Let's Talk, Learn, and Have Fun with Bruce & Friends S1E4 is now available! bit.ly/LTLHFwB0415

Student guest panel ROCKED. Nothing impressed more than a young adult yearning to understand.

"Nothing in life is to be feared, it is only to be understood. Now is the time to understand more, so that we may fear less." -Madame Curie.

See you next Wednesday when we'll take more of your questions and find out what's happening across the best school district in the nation!

post_text:
Strength in agility and alliances makes our LISD Super Kid Emma Heckler an outstanding student no matter where she’s learning!

Emma pursues excellence every day. The fourth-grader at Jim Plain Elementary has made it even more evident in the way she’s handled remote learning. Emma stays super positive about the circumstances and knows that at the end of the day, she is in charge of her own learning. She has taken a lot of responsibility to complete schoolwork at home and continues to strive for quality work and her best effort!

However, we also wanted to celebrate Emma for the things unseen in our new, atypical classroom settings. Emma is a good friend to others. She shows trust, kindness and sets a good example.

“Emma is the epitome of an all-around great young role model,” Plain Elementary fourth grade teacher Kaia Dock said. “She treats every person with respect and demonstrates what hard work can do for a person.”

We are beaming with pride for LISD Super Kid Emma Heckler!

post_text:
Join us Wednesday, April 15 for our latest episode of Let’s Talk, Learn, and Have Fun with Bruce & Friends at 4:30pm on Facebook LIVE.

LISD Superintendent Bruce Gearing, Ed.D. will answer some questions to some “Hot Topics”. Plus, we will also discuss the launch of our Remote Learning Parenting Hub, which went live online last week.

We want to continue our theme of connecting with families and students. You’ll hear from six high school students, one from every LISD high school campus. We know there’s been a lot of questions and concerns about graduation ceremonies and grading.

This is a great way to stay connected with Dr. Gearing and the district leadership team as we continue to build strong relationships. We feel like giving you honest answers is the best way to share the news of what motivates our decisions.

Our Facebook page is open to the public, so you do not need to be a Facebook user to access it. Any member of our public can ask us questions throughout the week on Let’s Talk.

post_text:
Our closed schools have meant more than just missing out on learning. It also makes us realize how much our campuses are the pulse of our school communities. That’s why we can appreciate LISD Volunteer of the Week Joanne Peacock even more!

The former Reagan Elementary PTA president immerses herself in all things fun for students. During her leadership, she spearheaded major events like the book fair, international fair, fun run and carnival. Her volunteer spirit kept her involved even after her term.

“Joanne has invested much of her time into supporting our Reagan community,” Reagan Elementary principal Marianne Norman said. “She is always willing to serve and support in any way that we need. We appreciate the time that she gives back to our campus.”

With a servant’s heart, Joanne also provides leadership for student after-school activities, Math Pentathlon and Destination Imagination.

Thank you Leander ISD Volunteer of the Week Joanne Peacock for keeping the campus heartbeat alive and well!

post_text:
The big brass band is buzzing for Leander ISD Fine Arts Student of the Week Kirsten Tjelmeland!

A standout tuba player at Four Points Middle, 8th-grader Kirsten excels as section leader and has made All-Region Band the last two years. Her commitment to excellence means more than just achieving personal success; it highlights her willingness to help others.

“Kirsten voluntarily uses her lunch hour to come and play alongside the sixth-grade tuba class, offering inspiration for younger students to continue making music for years to come,” said FPMS band director Jessica Gonzales. “She is a leader in the band by her actions, by her perseverance and by her example.”

When she’s not playing the tuba, Kirsten excels in basketball and track for FPMS.

For her leadership and dedication to helping sustain musical excellence at her school, a resounding “Oompah!” for LISD Fine Arts Student of the Week Kirsten Tjelmeland!

post_text:
Parkside Elementary School first-grader Avery Linscott showcases her agility and her pursuit of excellence as this week’s LISD Super Kid.

At a time when students are learning remotely, Avery works hard to stay connected to the classroom. Even if she’s confused on assignments, Avery gives her best effort and checks for understanding. She completes all assignments using Seesaw and is always excited to share what she’s doing at home.

“Avery’s family likes to make fun, silly videos on Instagram,” Parkside first-grade teacher Heather Moseley said. “They are a ray of light during this difficult time.”

Avery’s can-do attitude and willingness to be flexible also comes in handy when she practices her favorite activity, gymnastics. Whether learning or playing, she’s ready to meet the challenge.

“Avery has a fun, bubbly side and a serious, shyer side. She knows when it is appropriate to bring out each side, making her a great role model to all!”

Congratulations, LISD Super Kid Avery Linscott!

post_text:
Congratulations to Leander ISD Volunteer of the Week Laura Nasipak, who goes above and beyond for Winkley Elementary!

As the PTA VP of Communications, Laura diligently facilitates timely and important information through partnering with the school on our weekly campus communications. Laura also writes and shares a monthly PTA newsletter. She takes it upon herself to research and develop new programs and opportunities to enhance our Winkley community.

“Great or small, Laura graciously helps us with tasks every day,” Winkley principal Davina Stringer said. “We are so thankful for her partnership and dedication to sharing our vision of ‘Innovation & Excellence’.”

In honor of a parent-volunteer who not only writes for Winkley, but has become a vibrant part of its story, we are grateful for Laura Nasipak–LISD Volunteer of the Week!

post_text:
ICYMI Before the coronavirus pandemic took us out of classrooms, we visited 21 schools with our non-profit partner the Leander ISD Educational Excellence Foundation for our Spring Grant Patrol. See the moments and the passion from our teachers when LEEF awarded $22,804 at 31 classrooms. With the help of these grants, Leander ISD staff received resources for professional development, acceptance and commitment training for special education, podcast creation, QUEST resources and more.

You can create these moments by joining the LEEF Classroom Impact Team by donating monthly to support learning throughout LISD. Learn more at leeftx.org/donate.

post_text:
Rouse High School's record-breaking athlete and future Houston Baptist University Husky Isaiah Cash is taking a bite out of success as the Leander ISD Student-Athlete of the Week.

Isaiah, a senior on the Raider football and track and field teams, was a first-team all-district safety and academic all-district selection. His hard work on the field and in the classroom earned him a scholarship to play football at HBU. Before track season was put on hold, Isaiah was having an outstanding season and had already set three new school records in three different events!

“Isaiah is a very unique athlete,” Rouse Raider boys track coach Kevin Ellison said. “He is blessed on so many levels and always credits his outstanding support system for his successes. Isaiah leads our track program by example.”

For his exceptional hard work and dedication, we are proud to name Raider Nation's Isaiah Cash as the LISD Student-Athlete of the Week!

post_text:
What comes next? The Leander ISD Board of Trustees discussed the district’s next steps for responding to the coronavirus global pandemic as the number of confirmed cases across the United States continues to grow. Travis and Williamson counties are under shelter-in-place orders through April 13.

In a virtual meeting, the Board advised the district to extend the closure of normal school operations through April 13 to align with the counties’ directive, while also preparing families, students, and staff for a closure that could continue past that date.

The Board also extended the contract for SFE for child nutrition services, approved new instructional materials for high school English Language Arts classes, and hired a new principal for Laura Welsh Bush Elementary School.

Read the details in our board briefs ➡ bit.ly/3dz6TmX

post_text:
With campus and public libraries closed, we know this has been a tough time for all our voracious readers in Leander ISD. Fortunately, students can access eBooks and audiobooks via our digital library, Sora. Leander ISD’s virtual library provides the quickest and easiest ways to read or listen to digital titles in our schools. Users can simply log in using school credentials and instantly access hundreds of ebooks and audiobooks virtually on any device.

To get started, download the free Sora app for Android or IOS, or visit http://soraapp.com

In addition, LISD students and employees can access additional ebook and audiobook titles by connecting to Austin, Cedar Park or Leander public libraries if they are current library card holders. Simply click on the Add a Public Library link within the Sora app or the Sora desktop link.

Login and technical support information can be found at https://bit.ly/lisdreads or you can contact your Leander ISD campus librarian for assistance!
text:
With campus and public libraries closed, we know this has been a tough time for all our voracious readers in Leander ISD. Fortunately, students can access eBooks and audiobooks via our digital library, Sora. Leander ISD’s virtual library provides the quickest and easiest ways to read or listen to digital titles in our schools. Users can simply log in using school credentials and instantly access hundreds of ebooks and audiobooks virtually on any device.

To get started, download the free Sora app for Android or IOS, or visit http://soraapp.com

In addition, LISD students and employees can access additional ebook and audiobook titles by connecting to Austin, Cedar Park or Leander public libraries if they are current library card holders. Simply click on the Add a Public Library link within the Sora app or the Sora desktop link.

Login and technical support information can be found at https://bit.ly/lisdreads or you can contact your Leander ISD campus librarian for assistance!

We are facing an unprecedented, international event with the Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) as it spreads across the world and throughout Texas. While today is the start of our Spring Break, we know these issues are on the hearts and minds of our entire Leander ISD family and community.

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, we will be suspending normal school operations for the two weeks following Spring Break, through April 5, 2020.

post_text:
Grit & perseverance with a sense of humor to boot. That’s what defines LISD Super Kid Jahsua Tavarez!

The Grandview HillsElementary kindergartener doesn’t know the word "quit." However, that’s not why Jah was nominated. No, Eagle Nation wanted to recognize his constant concern for others. From the moment he greets his teacher and friends and all throughout the day, Jah makes every effort to be inclusive to all. A natural born leader, Jah rushes to help anyone who might be hurt on the playground and is always the first to say a kind word to whomever he encounters.

“Jah’s positive attitude and very clever sense of humor keep everyone laughing,” Patricia Robertson, Grandview Hills Elementary kindergarten teacher said. “He exudes concern for others by the gentle, but funny way he cheers people up with his jokes!”

For his always-helpful, extroverted, happy, positive, fun, extraordinary personality, there’s no gags about it! We’re delighted by LISD’s Super Kid Jahsua Tavarez. Congratulations!

We have an update to our ongoing response to the #covid19 global outbreak. While there are no cases in our district, we are operating under an abundance of caution, knowing that we need to serve all students. We are continuing to work with and monitoring the situation with our partners in the CDC, Texas Health and Human Services Commission, and Texas Education Agency.

As a result, we are canceling out-of-state travel for our students and staff. We will continue to update our families, teachers, and staff as we get new information.

📰 Updates ➡️ https://bit.ly/39K67Bg
ℹ️Details 👉 https://bit.ly/3aMnVf5

post_text:
Preparing for growth with infrastructure and the stress caused by grades and class rank rose to the top of the thoughts from the Vandegrift High School community conversation on student experience, which launched on Thoughtexchange after the Feb. 17 meeting with families, students and staff in VHS feeder schools.

“Another access road to Vandegrift. It’s dangerous that a school this size does not have another exit road,” wrote one of the commenters.

VHS and its feeder schools had an opportunity to share feedback, ideas and thoughts about how students experience school from Feb. 17 – March 2 as part of a Thoughtexchange.

Review the entire report, including all of the submissions here. bit.ly/2IQiLmB

“After visiting with students at Vandegrift and meeting with families in that community, we know this is a caring community focused on providing support for the whole child,” Superintendent Bruce Gearing, Ed.D. said. “I want to thank our participants for weighing in. We look forward to disseminating this data and bringing forth continuous improvement to these schools.”

We look forward to disseminating this data and bringing forth continuous improvement to these schools.”

post_text:
Leander ISD Volunteer of the Week Stephani Bercu is on a mission to make Running Brushy Middle School the best place to learn.

Stephani leads RBMS PTA as its president. Practically the embodiment of service, she has resurrected the importance and relevance of the organization at her campus. She works tirelessly to ensure the PTA is supporting students, parents, and staff. RBMS principal Jim Rose believes Stephani makes the entire organization better because of her leadership.

“Like many of our fantastic volunteers, she believes in and models ‘doing right and good by all,’” Rose said. “[You can see it] not only in our RBMS community, but in the greater Cedar Park and Leander communities as well.”

Stephani levels up with high schoolers too, where her care and thoughtfulness helps her chair Leander High School’s Parent Teacher Student Association.

Congratulations to our Volunteer of the Week Stephani Bercu for living up to a reputation of giving 100% effort for every single student.

Rutledge Elementary 3rd-graders learned about students with disabilities as part of the Kids First program. PTA parents, many of whom have children with special needs, led the interactive presentation that focused on three disabilities (autism, dyslexia and Down syndrome).

Through multimedia, activities and Q&A sessions, students learned about the challenges these disabilities present and how to help their classmates to feel included and supported.

post_text:
Her reign as captain of the Rouse Royals Dance Team earns Abbey Wilson the prestige of being the Leander ISD Fine Arts Student of the Week.

For the past three years, Abbey has chasséd her way into leadership. From second lieutenant to captain, her natural ability to call the shots helps nourish the competitive spirit of her fellow Royals. Adorned with numerous solo champion awards, the graduating senior can’t help but step into the spotlight.

“Abbey is a phenomenal dancer, choreographer and leader,“ RouseHigh Schooldance team director Amy McKee said. “She constantly strives to improve not only her dance technique, but her team as well.”

Congratulations to high-stepping Rouse royalty, Abbey Wilson, LISD’s Fine Arts Student of the Week!

post_text:
One of our Leander ISD’s “Leader In Me” campuses features our LISD Super Kid, Sonia Elise Grogono.

The fifth-grade standout is making her final year at Reed Elementary memorable by embracing many leadership roles on campus. As a member of the Lighthouse Team, Sonia understands the importance of being a good role model. Lighthouse Teams bolster the Leader in Me model, a student empowerment program that uses leadership and life-readiness skills to prepare students for future success.

Sonia’s strengths lie in her accountability, fairness and respect for herself and others – skills that help make her successful when working on a challenging project with her Destination Imagination team or keeping students out of harm’s way as a member of the safety patrol.

“She is like a mini principal,” Reed Elementary principal Paige Collier said. “She can run the school if you let her!”

We know big things are in store for Sonia because she’s already doing big things at Reed! Congratulations to this LISD Super Kid!

post_text:
Over 500 current and future Leander High School Lions participated in the online conversation on Student Experience, rallying around ideas concerning school and classroom size, individual plans for every student, and high-quality teachers.

LHS and its feeder schools had the opportunity after the Feb. 10 community meeting until Feb. 24 to share open-ended feedback on Thoughtexchange.

Review the entire report, including all of the submissions here --> bit.ly/2vCn0Pm. We will release the final report in June, which will also include submissions from the entire district.

“We want to thank our Lions and future Lion families for providing feedback in our community meetings and on Thoughtexchange,” Superintendent Bruce Gearing, Ed.D. said. “We are here to listen as we continue this conversation because we know the voices of our students, teachers, staff, families, and partners can only make us better.”

Over 500 current and future Leander High School Lions participated in the online conversation on Student Experience, rallying around ideas concerning school and classroom size, individual plans for every student, and high-quality teachers.

LHS and its feeder schools had the opportunity after the Feb. 10 community meeting until Feb. 24 to share open-ended feedback on Thoughtexchange.

Review the entire report, including all of the submissions here --> bit.ly/2vCn0Pm. We will release the final report in June, which will also include submissions from the entire district.

“We want to thank our Lions and future Lion families for providing feedback in our community meetings and on Thoughtexchange,” Superintendent Bruce Gearing, Ed.D. said. “We are here to listen as we continue this conversation because we know the voices of our students, teachers, staff, families, and partners can only make us better.”

Our Leander ISD Volunteer of the Week Nicole Dorris is one special lady who has a way of making those around her feel special!

Nicole volunteers at Rouse High School where she answers every request with enthusiasm and excitement. Her way of asking for donations from parents and business has meant Rouse’s Principal Student Leadership group has never gone without during their meetings.

“She has this special way of spoiling our teachers and staff throughout the year with “sweets”, breakfast, lunch, etc.,” Rouse High School principal Christine Simpson said. “ Our students and staff love to see her smiling face and can-do attitude.”

Thank you to Leander ISD’s Volunteer of the Week Nicole Dorris for showing Raider Nation the treasure of your selfless character1

post_text:
The Board approved an attendance zoning charter that prioritizes relieving overcrowding and keeping students zoned to schools close to their homes for the 2021-2022 school year. The approval came after community feedback from more than 1,600 people.

With 1,300 new students entering LISD schools every year and the expectation of one new school opening every year, the district is moving towards its plan for Tarvin Elementary School, opening August 2021. The facilities team will publish a scenario map and send it to potentially impacted schools next week.
Check out board briefs Feb. 27 --> bit.ly/3cgAv83
For more on zoning --> bit.ly/38JF60h

post_text:
A small part for a truly small actor is causing a big scene for Kamryn Tatum! The Block House Creek Elementary School fifth-grader is stealing the show as our LISD Fine Arts Student of the Week.

Kamryn had the chance to work with Rouse High School students in their production of “Les Miserables” in the role of Young Cosette. She exemplified great leadership in dedicating months of preparation.

“Keeping up with her grades and spending time with her family help keep her balanced in the world of academics and the arts,” Block House Creek Elementary performing arts teacher Mary Ann Loesch said. “We are very proud of how hard Kamryn works to be a leader in all areas!”

At the end of the day, Kamryn shows a heart full of love for music as an active member of the BHC Show Choir and Honor Choir. She has been involved in several Block House Creek Elementary productions such as “Aladdin Kids” and currently, “Willy Wonka Kids.”

For belting out the best of kindness, hard work and contagious positivity, a round of applause for our Fine Arts Student of the Week Kamryn Tatum!

post_text:
Leander ISD fifth-grade students are finishing up tours of middle schools, deciding on electives and meeting new faces. As they start to close the books on elementary school, so are some of their outstanding parents, many of whom have invested years of support into our campuses.

A great example of our selfless parents is our LISD Volunteer of the Week, Jenni Sellers. Jenni serves the Reagan Elementary PTA in many ways, but may leave the biggest shoes to fill as the chair for the PTA carnival. For the past four years, she has helped turn the school carnival into a premiere event. As Jenni’s fifth-grader prepares to leave Reagan, so is Jenni.

“She will be missed,” Reagan Elementary receptionist Kim Gogulski said. “We would like to thank Jenni for her years of selfless service.”

Congratulations to our Volunteer of the Week, Jenni Sellers, for being Reagan Ray-diant in her commitment to our kids!

post_text:
A trio of LISD student-athletes took home UIL state wrestling titles, while four other grapplers pinned podium finishes. The district sent a total of 26 state qualifiers to the tournament in Cypress, Texas on Feb. 22.

Individual State Champions were:

Ben Russo-Bell – Cedar Park High School, 5A Boys 220-pound division
Luke Sloan – Vandegrift High School, 6A Boys 138-pound division
A.J. Lofton – Vista Ridge High School, 6A Boys 152-pound division

Overall, LISD had a total of seven wrestlers medal finish in the top three. Other medalists include:

2nd place: Mea Mohler – Glenn High School, 5A Girls 138-pound division
3rd place: Ronald Caldwell – Cedar Park High School, 5A Boys 182-pound division
3rd place: Kallon Guyton – Glenn High School, 5A Boys 195-pound division
3rd place: Noah Gochberg – Vandegrift High School, 6A Boys 126-pound division
Congratulations to all of these talented wrestlers!

Families and students preferred school size and proximity to be the driving factors for new elementary school attendance boundaries in 2021–2022, according to community feedback offered through a Thoughtexchange forum.

With nine elementary schools projected to exceed 120 percent enrollment capacity in the next five years and 1,300 new students enrolling in Leander ISD every year, the district needs to open new schools and relieve overcrowding.

Read more in our Feb. 20 Board Briefs -> https://bit.ly/2ujeZ1c
Review the final report from our Thoughtexchange -> https://bit.ly/2T0w8VM
See more on attendance zoning -> https://bit.ly/3c7kT6O

We want to listen and learn from our community about how we can support various communities within Leander ISD. To help create meaningful and impactful dialogue, the district will begin its Community Conversations on Equity and Diversity with two community forums. These meetings – led by two college professors with extensive experience in fostering equity in public schools – will take place from 6–8 p.m. March 3 (Henry Middle School cafeteria) and March 9 (Wiley Middle School cafeteria). Join us!

Full details: bit.ly/32ie65O

post_text:
To a veteran who deserves recognition, not only in service to his country, but to Leander High School, we salute Mr. Robert Wren — LISD’s Volunteer of the Week.

Every Friday, Mr. Wren stands outside of the high school to greet students and staff. “Happy Friday” he says, offering everyone he encounters a warm way to start the day.

“Seeing members of our community interacting with our students and our parents, is something I wish we had more of,” LHS Principal Chris Simpson said. “His positivity and genuineness are something I look forward to every Friday.”

Congratulations, Mr. Wren you make us roar with Lion pride. 🦁

post_text:
A dance team rookie with an attitude en pointe: Cedar Park High School Sophomore Gwenevere Tharp has a stance for success as this week’s Fine Arts Student of the Week.

In her first year on the Celebrities Dance/Drill Team, Gwenevere shows a dedication like none other. She strives to improve her dance technique and performance quality by leaps and bounds. But, not for herself alone; she wants to see the whole squad positioned for success.

“We are so proud of her,” CPHS Dance/Drill Team Director Nikki Evans said. “She has an extremely strong work ethic and desire to grow as a dancer, leader and young woman.”

The show doesn’t stop there. From her classmates to the CPHS campus, Gwenevere provides a foundation of caring and passion.

Take a bow, Gwenevere! You’ve found your groove as LISD’s Fine Arts Student of the Week. Congratulations!

post_text:
A player on the field to a fan in the stands. Rouse High School Senior Alex Valerio is scoring goals in so many ways as LISD’s Student-Athlete of the Week.

Alex exemplifies leadership as a senior member and captain on the Lady Raider Soccer team. Her Raider pride bleeds into other school sports as a member of the spirit club Rockin’ Raiders. Her passion for blazing trails shows in her participation in two mentorship programs–Peer Assistance/Leadership (PALS) and the Amazing Raider Club–as well as serving on the Principal Student Advisory Committee.

“She is often the first to show up and last to leave practice,” Rouse Lady Raider Head Soccer Coach Katie Marek said. Marek has coached Alex for the last five years, watching her mature from an eighth-grader to a senior.

“She gives a voice to athletes that haven’t found theirs yet, positive and encouraging to everyone no matter their skill level.”

Alex, the world (cup) is your oyster! Congratulations for being our Student-Athlete of the Week.

post_text:
Bright, colorful flags and costumes abound at Reed Elementary School for International Day. The school hosted a parade led by Leander ISD Superintendent Dr. Bruce Gearing. In the spirit of his own tradition, clad in kilt, Dr. Gearing played bagpipes as he guided the procession of first-fifth grade students through the hallways. Reed’s more than 750 students waved with excitement as the traditional wears of more than a dozen countries passed them by.

ESL teacher Jose Rodriguez organized the event that helped stimulate cultural awareness and celebrate the multi-nationalism of the Reed community.

Check out more photos: bit.ly/2SpDqmU

post_text:
A River Ridge Elementary first-grader is getting the royal treatment for her kind and humble heart. This week’s Super Kid, Myreen Zaidi’s brilliance sparkles in her integrity.

Through the smallest gestures, Myreen shows care and compassion. Whether it’s helping someone clean out their desk, getting a jacket for a friend, opening a lunchbox, finding a lost piece of homework or sharpening a pencil, she’s so much more than a helpful hand. The definition of integrity–doing the right thing, even when no one is watching–truly defines Myreen.

“In my 20+ years of teaching, I have never met a kinder child,” River Ridge first-grade teacher Katie Haedge said. “I call her ‘Queen Myreen’ because she has such integrity, and everyone loves her because they see her shine in all that she does!”

Lest we not forget such character and class is coming from a first-grader, Myreen is setting an example of servant leadership for older students and throughout the River Ridge community.

We hereby decree a crown of glory for LISD’s Super Kid Myreen Zaidi! The pomp and circumstance is so richly deserved.

post_text:
Huge congrats to Naumann Elementary School Assistant Principal Mark Brown for being named the Region 13 AP of the Year by the Texas Elementary Principals and Supervisors Association (TEPSA)! He will be celebrated among other standout school leaders in June at the annual TEPSA awards.

“Mr. Brown is a longtime member of the Naumann family and he is very much part of the culture that makes Naumann such a great school,” NES Principal Shanita Kozlowski said. “Building and maintaining positive relationships is a key factor in the interactions he has with staff, students and parents. This recognition as Region 13 AP of the Year is well-deserved.”

Region Assistant Principals of the Year are eligible to apply for the National Assistant Principal of the Year. Congratulations, Mark!

post_text:
"Jill" of all trades, master of all! That's the story of our Volunteer of the Week, Dee Schaefer. Dee serves as Giddens Elementary School's PTA Treasurer. While that might seem like a notable contribution in and of itself, she's currently making up half the board!

As one of two PTA board members, Dee spends most days at the school, supporting teachers and students. Depending on the hour, she's wearing all kinds of hats: designer of the school yearbook, facilitator of the mentoring program Watch DOGS, recruiter for PTA membership. Sound crazy? She'd probably say that's accurate. But her "just try and keep up" attitude helps the vision of Giddens come to life.

"She is so supportive of our campus initiatives," Giddens Principal Sally Hill said. "She always has a positive attitude, a contagious laugh and is a bundle of energy! We love our Dee!"

Congratulations to Dee Schaefer, LISD's Volunteer of the Week!

post_text:
The click-clack of the keyboard strikes success for Vandegrift High School freshman Justin Heroux. The LISD Career and Technical Education Student of the Week is hitting the ground running in various CTE classes, typing twice as fast than your average typist!

Wanting to hone his already strong keyboarding technique, Justin dove into the EduTyping curriculum this school year. In just five months, he completed the program and consistently types 100 words per minute with high accuracy.

“Justin’s self-motivation is a privilege to witness,” Business Information Management teacher Kari Michalek said. “[He] and several classmates support each other and also compete against one another in keyboarding, creating a fun, friendly environment in the classroom.”

Justin’s initiative and hard work clearly make him worthy of the honor – LISD CTE Student of the Week. Congratulations!

Leander ISD is proud to honor and thank the more than 14,000 volunteers that make a difference in the lives of our students. From booster clubs to PTAs, H.E.R.O.E.S. mentors to Watch D.O.G.S., Literacy Partners and beyond, the greater Leander ISD community is creating the learning environments that help our students achieve their full potential.

For more information about our amazing volunteers and how you can get involved in our schools, please visit leanderisd.org/volunteer. Thank you to all of our volunteers that devote time and energy for the betterment of our schools!

Leander ISD is proud to announce Stiles Middle School’s Tian Murray as the Leander ISD Student-Athlete of the Week. Tian is a member of the Spartan eighth grade football, basketball and track teams.

Pushing himself on the field every day, Tian also works hard in the classroom. The A/B honor student also is an active member of Fellowship of Christian Athletes (FCA).

“Tian is blessed with natural abilities, but he still has a hard working attitude and strives to get better at whatever sport he is in,” Spartans 8th grade basketball coach, Jonathan Blissit said. “He has a ‘team first’ attitude.”

Congratulations to Tian Murray, of Stiles Middle School, Leander ISD Student-Athlete of the Week!

After moving from a small, Rhode Island town to the largest high school in Leander ISD senior Audrey Seed found a home at Vandegrift High School.

Destined for Texas State next year, Audrey went from a graduating class of 23 to almost 650 VHS students in the class of 2020. Through PALS and the help of counselors, Audrey writes about how VHS made her transition smooth.

Read Audrey’s story, featured on page 26 of the Texas School Business Magazine section on Student Voices. http://bit.ly/31xLULP

post_text:
Rutledge Elementary fifth grader Parker Traweek is stealing the show as LISD’s Fine Arts Student of the Week.

Wearing many hats, Parker has been instrumental in developing the school’s multiple fine arts programs and clubs. He has a lead role in Rutledge’s Spring Show, spending time out of class rehearsing and encouraging others to do the same. Parker also leads the RES Chorale and the Ukulele Club, performance groups made up of fourth and fifth graders who meet twice a week after school.

“He is a great asset to performing arts activities at Rutledge,” performance arts teacher Elaine Edwards said. “I’m so grateful for his high personal standards and his quiet leadership.”

A standing ovation for Parker Traweek, LISD’s Fine Arts Student of the Week!

Three cheers for Reagan Elementary School third grader Jacie Kasparzak, this week’s Leander ISD Super Kid! Jacie exemplifies LISD’s Ethical Principles by being 100% dependable and constantly working to make the world a better place.

“Jacie is one student that I can count on to not only do the right thing, but to be a leader,” teacher Melanie Rice said. “She encourages others to do so as well. This is especially important during math rotations when I am working with small groups.”

Congratulations, Jacie! You’re a Reagan Ray who’s making waves across the district!

post_text:
Leander ISD offers a profound “thank you” to Anitra Tovar, LISD’s Volunteer of the Week.

Anitra leads the volunteer team at Bagdad Elementary. She has become an essential part of the school community, reading to students and leading a Destination Imagination team. Anitra flexes her sewing talents, making costumes for the school play and dresses for the Ballet Folklorico team.

“Anitra is always there when we need her to step in to support our students and school to make it a better place to learn,“ Principal Christy Hilbun said. “Anitra should be named ‘Super Volunteer’!”

Because of her unwavering dedication in service to students, Leander ISD recognizes Anitra Tovar as the Volunteer of the Week!

post_text:
Leander ISD is proud to honor its more than 100 school counseling staff members throughout the district during National School Counseling Week, Feb. 3–7, 2020.

As valued members of our schools, counselors help students find their passion and purpose. They work with teachers and staff to help meet a child's needs, often bridging school and home. In providing a safe and trusted environment, LISD's school counselors and social workers help nurture a student's positive attitude about themselves, their education and their future.

The LISD Counseling Services staff includes:
° 11 social workers and licensed professional counselors
° 31 elementary school counselors
° 24 middle school counselors
° 39 high school counselors

We applaud the efforts of these remarkable LISD staff members who help students reach new heights in their academic, social and emotional journey.

post_text:
Leander ISD is proud to announce Vandegrift High School senior Greyson Powell as the district’s Career and Technical Education (CTE) Student of the Week.

Greyson is the district’s first student to take the Practicum in Business Management. A CTE practicum combines classroom learning with real-world application, a process that has confirmed for Greyson his desire to major in business and become an actuary.

“Greyson has networked with industry professionals, attended actuarial society workshops and even uses class time to study for one of many actuarial exams required of the profession,” VHS DECA advisor Kari Michalek said. “[His] curiosity and motivation to learn will yield him success as an LSU Tiger and as a future actuary.”

Congratulations to Vandegrift’s Greyson Powell, LISD’s CTE Student of the Week!

Leander ISD is proud to announce Vandegrift High School senior Greyson Powell as the district’s Career and Technical Education (CTE) Student of the Week.

Greyson is the district’s first student to take the Practicum in Business Management. A CTE practicum combines classroom learning with real-world application, a process that has confirmed for Greyson his desire to major in business and become an actuary.

“Greyson has networked with industry professionals, attended actuarial society workshops and even uses class time to study for one of many actuarial exams required of the profession,” VHS DECA advisor Kari Michalek said. “[His] curiosity and motivation to learn will yield him success as an LSU Tiger and as a future actuary.”

Congratulations to Vandegrift’s Greyson Powell, LISD’s CTE Student of the Week!

The University Interscholastic League (UIL) released the 2020–21 and 2021–22 football, basketball and volleyball district assignments. Realignment affects all UIL sports, but none more so than football, which has the most elaborate playoffs of all the sports with several classifications split into into two divisions based on enrollment numbers.

Vandegrift and Vista Ridge high schools will compete in Class 6A, while Cedar Park, Glenn, Leander and Rouse high schools are slotted in Class 5A. Read all about it: https://news.leanderisd.org/uil-announces-bi-annual-realignment/

Leander ISD is proud to announce Leander High School’s Eli Gehman as the Leander ISD Student-Athlete of the Week. Eli is a senior on the Lion football team and is a 3-year letterman and captain on the Lion soccer team. Eli is also a leader in FCA and a member of the National Honor Society. His dedication to academics earned Eli a spot on the THSCA Academic All-State and District 13-6A Academic All-District teams.

“Eli is a great athlete and great young man,” LHS football coach Kris Price said. “He serves as a positive role model for students and athletes in our building. His leadership abilities on and off the field, have made an impact on our programs that will be the foundation of future success.”

“Eli is a great leader to the team on the field as well as in the classroom,” LHS soccer Coach, Russ Girard added.

Congratulations to Eli Gehman of Leander High School, the Leander ISD Student-Athlete of the Week!

post_text:
Leander ISD sixth-grade social studies teachers helped launch a program that partners local social studies teachers with the Environmental Science and Conservation department of Concordia University Texas and the Westcave Outdoor Discovery Center.

The program encourages geography outdoor education (GEO) through the use of geographic information systems. Equipped with binoculars and game cameras, four LISD teachers practiced exploring the Concordia campus and used nature apps to determine the impact of development on the natural habitat of species.

The participating 6th grade teachers are:

- Kiann Betancourt and Amy Ballard from CRMS
- Brittney Phan SMS
- Sara Killian LMS
- Ashley Young WMS

“We hope to use the geography outdoor learning to provide enrichment opportunities to our students,” said Social Studies Facilitator, Amy Pokorney. “This is a great way for continued learning practices to impact their classrooms.”

This spring, teachers and a handful of students will have the opportunity to participate in a field study, using the equipment provided by Concordia.

post_text:
CPHS students say, “Get out there and VOTE!”

Leading up to the primary elections, Cedar Park High School juniors and seniors gathered in the gym Thursday for their first voting pep rally. Students from Rho Kappa, a Social Studies National Honor Society, created helpful presentations to educate their peers about voting, including information on:

- ballots and voting machines,
- the difference between primary and general elections, and
- what to bring/what not to bring to the polls.

Students who will turn 18 within the next two months registered to vote thanks to the Austin chapter of the League of Women Voters.

“I don’t want everyone else choosing who my president is going to be,” senior Aiden Mentel said, expressing a common sentiment at the pep rally. “I want my opinion to matter.”

All LISD high schools publicize voter registration through their Government and Economics classes. In addition, announcements are made prior to primary and local elections with voter registration efforts in the spring and fall.

So what are you waiting for? Let’s get out there and vote!

Steiner Ranch Elementary School’s Jill Moeller Serafine is the Leander ISD Volunteer of the Week! Jill leads and coordinates a variety of successful projects, fundraisers and initiatives each year.

Just a few of her amazing contributions include:
-heading up the Kindness Rocks painting,
-creating and training teachers to use a Motor Lab,
-coordinating the carnival auction, and
-supporting the Walking Wednesdays for families.

In addition to these accomplishments, Jill also assembles the school yearbook every year.

“Jill is a little bit of everything to everyone,” said Principal Angela Hodges. “She is always smiling, always looking for ways to help and is a huge part of why the SRE community is amazing!”

Vandegrift High School junior Anish Pandya is the Leander ISD Career and Technical Education (CTE) Student of the Week. Anish excels in multiple programs, including medical sciences, robotics and molecular biology!

Anish has been one of the key student leaders of Health Occupations Students of America (HOSA) at VHS, working to streamline & coordinate the HOSA competition process. He has personally reached out to many health professionals and coordinated guest speakers for the HOSA meetings. He qualified for HOSA State Competition for scoring 2nd in the Area 1 Pathophysiology Test. He is also an active member of VHS Robotics.

“This year, Anish has started a new student organization on the VHS campus geared towards molecular biology research and competition, ‘iGem’,” program instructor Karen Pearce said. “Anish’s passion for the medical sciences is evident in his contagious enthusiasm for HOSA and iGem activities.”

Leander ISD is proud to announce Vandegrift High School basketball standout Summer Ely as the LISD Student-Athlete of the Week. A senior, Summer is a National Merit Semifinalist and participates in Robotics, the Red Cross Club, the Unicef Club, the National Honor Society and the Spanish Honors Society!

“Summer is an incredible teammate on the court and in the locker room, always putting the team’s well-being in front of her own,” VHS Head Girls Basketball Coach Jonathan Jones said. “She comes to practice every day with enthusiasm, effort and great focus. Summer will never truly understand how much of an impact she has on our team and program. She is an awesome young lady, a joy to coach and has a bright future ahead of her.”

Congratulations to Summer Ely of Vandegrift High School, the Leander ISD Student-Athlete of the Week!

Sydney McCallum, a fourth-grade student at Reagan Elementary, is this week’s LISD Super Kid. She demonstrates her super-powers of “Loyalty” and “Concern for Others” by consistently giving of her time in the structured learning environment (SLE) classroom.

Sydney stops by every morning to check in with the students, helps a student get his breakfast and walks another student to class. She helps a fourth-grade peer with his communication system and volunteers her time during kindergarten PE to help special education students participate.

“Sydney shows a passion for caring for others and those with all abilities,” teacher Krista Spurgeon said. “She takes initiative, has a big heart for all, and is a joy to have in the reverse inclusion program.”

post_text:
LISD's Career and Technical Education Student of the Week just got a 4-YEAR FULL SCHOLARSHIP TO THE UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME!

Congratulations to Glenn High School senior Melany Gavira, who successfully helped launch the campus' Future Medical Professionals club. She played a huge role in providing ideas and goals for the organization and how it will be structured to benefit future GHS students. Melany has also helped with team building and serves a role model for many of the members in the club.

"The fact that she has received a scholarship of this magnitude simply proves that with intent and high expectations of yourself, you can achieve the unthinkable," advisor Leo Carranza said. "Many of my biomedical science students look up to Melany as a leader and role model. She has given them hope and motivation to become better versions of themselves. I am looking forward to seeing her contributions to society and the field of medicine in the future."

Congratulations to Glenn High School's Melany Gavira, a future Notre Dame undergrad and the LISD CTE Student of the Week!

post_text:
Board Briefs: District Launches Attendance Zoning Planning for 2021

Schools will add 1,300 students every year for the next 10 years, resulting in four elementary schools exceeding 120 percent of their designed capacity by 2021, the year LISD will open its 28th elementary school on the Ronald Reagan corridor.

The district will start asking community members what they want to achieve with the opening of Nancy Tarvin Elementary School, located in the Palmera Bluff subdivision beginning in August 2021. The project team hopes to learn the community’s priorities for a zoning plan. Community preferences typically include a focus on maintaining feeder patterns, relieving overcrowded schools, balancing enrollments, or minimizing changes for students. LISD expects to give families at least 12 months of advance notice before the plan goes into effect.

LISD expects to give families at least 12 months of advance notice before the plan goes into effect.

Board Briefs: Trustees Continue Discussion on Goals, District to Take Conversation to Community

Trustees discussed individual education plans for all students, a focus on early literacy, school choice, the Leander Way, and strategic planning during its continued discussion on the district’s goals. The district also presented details to the Board on the launch of six feeder-based community forums to support these discussions.

“For the first time since I've been in this district, the entire community is hearing what drives each Board member to be here,” Trustee Jim Mackay said. “Community-based accountability for me is our way to ensure our community has a seat at the table. It is critically important that we have these types of discussions here - in front of the community.”

Board members engaged in a lengthy and thoughtful discussion about objectives for the district to accomplish. They captured those items for continued discussion at its Jan. 23 regular meeting.

post_text:
Board Briefs: Board to Vote on PreK Expansion Proposal

The district expects its plan for expanding PreK from a half-day to a full-day program will grow from six community schools to 13 to accommodate an expected 94-percent increase in enrollment. With the adoption of House Bill 3, the state of Texas requires districts to offer full-day PreK for students who qualify (more info: www.leanderisd.org/prekindergarten).

Research shows 90 percent of brain development occurs before age 5. PreK increases kindergarten readiness, language acquisition, and the odds a child will read on grade level by third grade.

The district estimates the cost for PreK will be $4.2 million annually with an additional, first-year start-up expense of $2.5 million. The proposed plan would also include a limited tuition-based option to offset costs, allowing families who do not qualify for free PreK an opportunity to enroll their children. The Board could approve the proposal at its Jan. 23 meeting.

Research shows 90 percent of brain development occurs before age 5. PreK increases kindergarten readiness, language acquisition, and the odds a child will read on grade level by third grade.

The proposed plan would also include a limited tuition-based option to offset costs, allowing families who do not qualify for free PreK an opportunity to enroll their children. The Board could approve the proposal at its Jan. 23 meeting.

post_text:
Our awesome, amazing Leander ISD Volunteer of the Week is Cedar Park Middle School's Lauren Cafferty. Lauren has been a volunteer at CPMS for six years, dedicating her time in the library and doing a little bit of everything (organizing, labeling, examining books for repair, circulation, even student assistance!). She tackles big projects with exacting attention and her wry sense of humor is always a delight.

"With gentle thoughtfulness, she frequently provides me with suggestions I hadn't considered," CPMS librarian Julia Nations said. "Lauren is unassuming and avoids the spotlight, but she is an important, longtime partner of our library program here at CPMS. Additionally, she has volunteered several years in LISD as a coordinator for Reflections and a Destination Imagination evaluator. Lauren Cafferty is a jewel!"

post_text:
Leander ISD is proud to announce Glenn High School culinary student Summer Pate as the LISD Career and Technical Education (CTE) Student of the Week. Summer, a senior in Advanced Culinary Arts – ProStart, serves as the program’s vice president, spearheads the development of menu selection and supports practices for competition. She also gives of her personal time to support the program via open houses and community service.

“Summer is a true example of hard work and dedication,” program coordinator Olivia Rodriguez said. “Summer received one of the Austin Steam Train Association scholarships this year and she deserves it. She will continue her education in culinary arts after graduation and is a true example of finding your passion and following it through our CTE programs. I am so proud of her and excited to see her continued success.”

What’s the best way to earn cupcakes and extra recess? By being named a "Leader in Me" Lighthouse School by FranklinCovey Education! The recognition was a surprise, shared with Reed Elementary School students and staff, during an assembly on Monday, January 14th.

“We are honored to have been certified and named a 'Leader in Me' Lighthouse School,” said Reed Principal Paige Collier. “We have seen amazing results from implementing the Leader in Me process at our school, such as increased attendance rates, double-digit gains in academic test scores, and decreased discipline issues.”

Well done Roadrunners! We are so proud of you!

post_text:
Leander ISD is proud to announce Cedar Park High School's Elena Veninicasa as the Leander ISD Student-Athlete of the Week. Elena, a junior, is a standout member of the CPHS cheerleading and track & field teams.

Not only is Elena the parliamentarian for the National English Honor Society and an officer for the Spanish Honor Society, she is also a member of the National Honor Society, Science Honor Society and HOSA. She has won back-to-back 5A D1 State Championships with the cheer squad, runs the 4x100 relay and 4x200 relay, and participates in the long jump and triple jump events. Elena is obviously an outstanding student and talented athlete!

“Elena not only stands out academically and athletically, but she is a true leader within a program full of elite athletes" CPHS Head Cheer Coach Nadira King said. "She constantly impresses me with her ability to lead her teammates with great passion and respect. She is an amazing role model for the younger girls in the program.”

Congratulations to Elena Veninicasa, the Leander ISD Student-Athlete of the Week!

The Rouse Raider basketball teams hosted the Leander Lazers, the district's Special Olympics team, for a clinic today.

“The best part was seeing how happy we made them,” Rouse sophomore Mekai Coleman said. “I like communicating with them and giving them someone to look up to.”

The room was filled with joy and encouragement as parents, grandparents and friends cheered for their athletes.

“This is my favorite day of the year,” Rouse Basketball Coach Shane Krause said. “Players being coaches gives them the opportunity to give back to other students and it gives them all the chance to have fun together.”

Leander ISD is mindful of the severe weather conditions expected this evening. In the interest of safety, we are cancelling all after-school events to include athletic practices and games, fine arts activities and all other events.

The YMCA after-school program will provide care as usual to the students enrolled in the program. They are asking parents to pick their children up as early as possible from the program to provide the opportunity for students and staff to arrive home safely.

Please work with your student’s coach, teacher or program sponsor regarding changes to weekend schedules.

Thank you for your continued support of Leander ISD.

The Vandegrift High School Band has been chosen as the 2019 Sudler Shield Award Winner! The Sudler Shield is an international award recognizing "High School and International Marching Bands of World Class Excellence" and is administered by the John Philip Sousa Foundation.

Vandegrift HS is the third LISD school to receive the Sudler Shield, following CPHS in 2006 and VRHS in 2018.
